page.title: 09BUILDING MATERIALS
page.content: In this area the building materials used are often quite different from those employed in nearby Bristol or Bath. Local stone has long been quarried and used to build Mendip cottages and houses. Where builders employed lime mortar and lime washes,stone surrounds were often used to frame windows. Stone mullion windows are a common feature, with lead used to seal the glass to the stone. A lot of the roofs in this area are covered by clay tiles. The school at the centre of Chewton Mendip is a good example (597,531). Some of the best examples of slate roofs on traditional cottages are along the Folly (596,527). Slate, for many years has been quarried in South Wales and bought back by boat or road to England.
